text: marches by student nurses and midwives
in protest of plans in England to scrap
state-funded bursaries from August
nurses and midwives starting training
will need to take out student loans as
with other courses the government argues
this will encourage universities to
create a lot more places but you caste
figures showed university applications
were nearly a quarter lower this year in
England labour says if elected it will
restore the bursaries due to be scrapped
in August the party also wants to end
the 1% pay cap for health staff it says
its policies will be paid for by
reversing corporation tax cuts labour
also plans to get regulators to draw up
guidelines on safe staffing in hospitals
and then legislate to make hospitals
abide by them well we think it's deeply
unfair that our NHS staff have to suffer
form a 1% pay cap continually under this
conservative government we're saying
we're going to scrap that cap we're
going to give our NHS staff the pay they
deserve and we're going to ask the
independent public sets of pay bodies to
look at the evidence again and come
forward with a fair package for any our
NHS staff because they deserve better
than what they're getting under this
Conservative government but the
Conservatives argued that Labour's
funding planned for the measures didn't
stack up there's always a case for
paying nurses more they work extremely
hard but labour have already promised
this money from corporation tax twelve
times they promised it for university
tuition fees for the schools budget and
if you don't really have that money if
you then lift that pick up what you end
up having to do is to employ fewer
nurses and that means less safe hospital
wards the Liberal Democrats said labour
was not being honest with the public
about the revenue raised to pay for the
policies q PM BBC News
